metadata.case_name: Appellant (Retired Superintendent of Police) v. Respondent (Income-tax authorities)

facts.text: Appellant was a Superintendent of Police in the service of the former Travancore State and retired sometime in 1940.

After retirement, appellant spent time studying Vedanta philosophy and expounding it to disciples, including J. Levy of London, U.K., who visited Travancore regularly from England to attend discourses.
On December 13, 1941, Levy transferred Rs. 2,41,103-11-3 from his Lloyds Bank account in Bombay to an account opened in appellant's name in the same bank.
Levy made further deposits into appellant's Lloyds Bank account, totaling about Rs. 4,50,000 up to August 19, 1951.
Appellant transferred moneys from Lloyds Bank Bombay to his account in a bank at Trivandrum in Travancore from time to time.
Assessment years 1122, 1123, 1124 (Malayalam era): Gregorian periods August 17, 1945 to August 16, 1946; August 17, 1946 to August 16, 1947; August 17, 1947 to August 16, 1948.
During relevant periods, Levy deposited Rs. 13,304; Rs. 29,948; Rs. 19,983 into appellant's Bombay account.
During same periods, appellant transferred Rs. 81,200; Rs. 47,000; Rs. 37,251 from Bombay to Trivandrum account.
Income-tax Officer, Trivandrum, assessed appellant on the transferred amounts as foreign income brought into Travancore.
Appellant appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner, who dismissed the appeal and confirmed ITO orders.

Tribunal referred two questions to Travancore-Cochin High Court: (1) Whether receipts from John H. Levy constitute income taxable under Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121? (2) Whether materials to hold deposits represented income accrued outside Travancore?
High Court answered first question affirmatively; second in favor of appellant, holding income arose in Travancore from vocation.
Appellant obtained special leave to appeal to Supreme Court against High Court's answer to first question.
No evidence that appellant conditioned teaching on payment.
Levy's affidavit: Sums were gifts to mark esteem and affection; he benefited from appellant's teachings on Vedanta.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant was carrying on a vocation by teaching Vedanta philosophy.
Whether the amounts received from John H. Levy constitute profits or gains of that vocation and are taxable as income under the Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121.
Whether the receipts from John H. Levy constitute income taxable under the Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121?

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant was not carrying on a vocation as teaching Vedanta was without motive or intention of making profit, not organised, and akin to practicing religion.
Payments by Levy were purely personal gifts, not connected to vocation.
Vocation requires profit motive and organised activity.

respondent_arguments.text: Receipts constitute income from vocation of teaching Vedanta.

court_reasoning.text: Teaching Vedanta is a vocation, equivalent to any teaching; no requirement for profit motive or organisation beyond systematic activity, which was present (regular disciples, Levy's visits).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Motive of profit not essential; if activity produces income, it is taxable regardless of intention.

court_reasoning.text: Payments by Levy were received by virtue of appellant's vocation; test is from donee's standpoint, whether accrued by virtue of office/vocation; not personal gifts as they resulted from teaching (causa causans).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Regular payments linked to regular visits for instruction; esteem arose from teaching.

court_reasoning.text: No exemption under s.4(3)(vii) as payments arose from exercise of vocation.

holdings.text: Appellant was carrying on a vocation by teaching Vedanta.
Receipts from Levy constitute taxable income as profits/gains from the vocation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Inland Revenue v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting
precedents_cited.relevance: Profit motive not essential for business, profession or vocation.
Pension not taxable absent office; not applicable as no profit motive required.
Test for voluntary payments: from recipient's standpoint, if by virtue of office.
Voluntary payment taxable if by virtue of office.
Test: personal gift or remuneration? If latter, taxable.
Offerings to vicar taxable as from office, despite esteem.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore Income-tax Act, 1121
sections: Equivalent to s.10, s.4(3)(vii) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Tax on profits/gains of vocation; no exemption for payments from vocation.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions identical for present purpose; tax on vocation income.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's answer that receipts from Levy constitute taxable income from appellant's vocation of teaching Vedanta; not concerned with second question decided in appellant's favor.

key_quotes.text: it is not the motive of the person doing an act which decides whether the act done by him is the carrying on of a business, profession or vocation. If any business, profession or vocation in fact produces an income, that is taxable income
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle rejecting profit motive requirement.

key_quotes.text: the test is whether, from the standpoint of the person who receives it, it accrues to him in virtue of his office
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.relevance: Test for taxability of voluntary payments.

key_quotes.text: the imparting of the teaching was the causa causans of the making of the gift it was not merely a causa sine qua non.
key_quotes.speaker: court
